page.title: 04LANDSCAPE Local History
page.content:
There are three hostelries in the village,The Royal Oak,The White Horse built on the site of the old workhouse, and The Nag's Head,the reputed haunt of Dick Turpin, the highwayman hanged in York for stealing a horse from Heckington Fen.
The village is still served by a rail link to Sleaford and Boston and allows access to the main line station at Grantham. Adjacent to the station is the Pearoom Heritage Centre, an old pea sorting building now converted for use by craftsmen using traditional skills and other rural pursuits.The station, Pearoom and mill form the nucleus of one of the light industrial areas giving wider diversity of employment to the people of the area.
